Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Theories and Experiments on Scalar Mixing in Chaotic Flows
Award.AbstractNarration:
Tang
DMS-1212144
Ouellette
DMS-1211952

The investigators model and quantify scalar diffusion in the limit where homogenization theory is invalid. This regime is typical when the scalar in the flow has sources or sinks due to physical or biological forces, such as release or mitigation of contaminants, birth and death processes, predator-prey interactions in biological species, or many others. As a result, the classical assumptions of turbulent isotropy and homogeneity do not apply, and the mathematical challenge is to properly represent enhanced diffusion (from molecular motion) by the associated fluid motion at scales smaller or comparable to the characteristic forcing scale of the flow. The complementary expertise of the investigators enables the development of mathematically based models that are verified with numerical and physical experiments. The investigators study scalar mixing from a variety of angles. Topological measures on the background stirring, based on dynamical systems methods, are used and tested for modeling turbulent diffusion with coherent structures. Additionally, mixing measures associated with sources and sinks are studied with an upper bound approach. Overall, the investigators study how mathematical theory can be used and adapted to explain inhomogeneous, anisotropic diffusion processes observable from physical experiments.

Transport and mixing processes associated with pollutants, such as the Gulf oil spill and radioactive contamination in Japan, and with biological tracers, such as plankton blooms, are greatly affected by stirring patterns in the background flow. The novel theoretical and experimental studies proposed here lay the foundation for improved mathematical models and simulations of scalar mixing for many environmental and geophysical processes; in particular, they can be used to address realistic environmental problems. Other broad impacts include training of a graduate student and a postdoctoral researcher. Moreover, the experiments and visualizations from simulations, along with some analytical and computational tools used in this research, are blended into the investigators' outreach efforts to engage high school students' interest in mathematics and physics. The project is supported by the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems and by the Division of Mathematical Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chaotic and turbulent fluid flows mix very efficiently: if a small, discrete patch of some impurity is initially introduced into the fluid, it will very quickly be smeared out and dispersed. When the amount of impurity is fixed, it is expected that after a long time its distribution will be statistically uniform, and the fluid will be homogenized. The mixing process can then be mathematically described as an approach to this homogeneous state. But when there are sources or sinks, chemical reactions, or other processes at work that make the long-time state more complicated, modeling the way the impurity mixes is much more challenging. In this project, we undertook a joint experimental and mathematical study of mixing by chaotic and turbulent flows under these non-ideal conditions. In particular, we sought to understand how the presence of coherent structures (that is, dynamically self-organized distinguished regions in the flow) interacted with transported material to shape the mixing process.

Experimentally, this project specifically looked at the evolution of reaction fronts in the oscillatory, autocatalytic Belousov-Zhabotinsky chemical reaction in the presence of unsteady flow. Experimental methods were developed to isolate these reaction fronts from high-speed imaging studies of the flow and to quantify their motion. Detailed comparisons of the experimental results with numerical models are ongoing but promising.

In addition, the experimental and analysis tools and ideas developed to study the primary questions of this project were also extended to address different, though related, problems. To determine how mixing is related to the nonlinear dynamics of energy and momentum transfer, an analysis tool based on spatially localized spectral filtering was developed. With partial support from this project, the resolution limits of this tools were fully characterized. Much of the analysis of the experimental data produced during this project was conducted from a Lagrangian viewpoint, where the trajectories of individual elements of the fluid are considered. We found that in addition to their utility in studying mixing, these Lagrangian ideas could be expanded to shed new light on longstanding questions in the geometric alignment of vorticity and strain in turbulence. A new diagnostic for mixing based on the curving of fluid-element trajectories was developed and studied experimentally, and the relationship between the coherent structures in the flow field and the way the flow is driven was studied. And finally, we also took the tools developed here for characterizing mixing and applied them to the problem of the mixing and transport of chemicals in the human airway during olfaction. The research supported by this grant has led to the publication of several journal articles.

This project also had several broader impacts. Several junior researchers were trained in interdisciplinary research, and the results of this project were communicated broadly across different fields where mixing plays a role. And finally, several software tools developed during this project were made freely available to the research community.
